Package de.hu.gralog.beans

This package and it's subpackages define all classes that are needed to implement and use JavaBeans in GrALoG.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
BeanUtil Provides Utility-functions for beans used by GrALoG.
 

Package de.hu.gralog.beans Description

This package and it's subpackages define all classes that are needed to implement and use JavaBeans in GrALoG.

GrALoG makes intensive use of the JavaBeans-Framework ( see Java Bean Specification ) in order to define it's Algorithms, Structure-Beans, vertices and edges. The reason for this is that JavaBeans defines a solid Framework, that can be used to construct and define objects with arbitrary properties, that can be administrated via a GUI.

Algorithms, Structure-Beans, vertices and edges use JavaBeans to define their properties, PropertyEditors, Customizers and / or PersistenceDelegates, thus it is important for you to understand the basics of JavaBeans. The next section provides a number of examples that illustrate the use of JavaBeans in GrALoG.

Plugin-Developers

Every time you have to implement an algorithm, a structure-bean, a vertex and / or an edge in GrALoG you have to define a JavaBean. But what is a JavaBean and which features of JavaBeans can you use in GrALoG?

The JavaBeans-Framework allows you to construct objects that take arbitrary properties and to provide GUI-components, descriptions and persistence-features to these objects, that allow the user to customize, load and save them.

Lets start with a simple example of a JavaBean that has a label: 

        public class MyBean {
                private String label;
                
                public MyBean() {
                        setLabel( "" );
                }

                public String getLabel() {
                        return label;
                }
                
                public void setLabel( String label ) {
                        this.label = label;
                }
        }
You can see from this example that every property of a JavaBean has a pair of functions associated with it, the so called getter- and setter-methods. These functions are later used by GrALoG to retrieve and set the properties for this bean. Since the JavaBeans-Framework provides a huge amount of default-functionality for JavaBeans, GrALoG would already be able to customize and store this bean - using the Default- PropertyEditor and PersistenceDelegate for this bean. But as soon as you want to implement more sophisticated properties and behaviour for your bean, you have to know how to associate Property-Editors, Customizers and PersistenceDelegates to it. The easiest way to achieve this is to define a class named MyBeanBeanInfo in the same package as your bean that extends SimpleBeanInfo and should look something like this: 

public class MyBeanBeanInfo extends SimpleBeanInfo {
        private static final BeanDescriptor BEAN_DESCRIPTOR = new BeanDescriptor( MyBean.class, MyBeanCustomizer.class );
        private static final PropertyDescriptor[] PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS = new PropertyDescriptor[1];
        
        static {
                /**
                * Sets the DisplayName of this beans. This feature is only supported for GrALoG-Algorithms.
                */
                BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setDisplayName( "A name for this bean to be displayed in GrALoG" );

                /**
                * Sets the shortDescripton of this beans. This feature is only supported for GrALoG-Algorithms.
                */
                BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setShortDescription( 
                        "" +
                        "An html-description for this Bean to be displayed by GrALoG"
                        "" 
                        );
                                
                /**
                * Sets the PersistenceDelegate for this Bean, that is used by GrALoG to store the bean.
                */
                BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setValue( "persistenceDelegate", new MyBeanPersistenceDelegate() );

                try {           
                        /**
                        * Define the properties of your Bean using PropertyDescriptor
                        */
                        PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0] = new PropertyDescriptor( "label", MyBean.class );
                        PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0].setShortDescription( "" +
                                                "a description for this property which is displayed by GrALoG" +
                                                ""
                                                );
                } catch( IntrospectionException e ) {
                        e.printStackTrace();
                }
        }
        
        /**
        * These methods need to be overriden in order to allow
        * GrALoG to retrieve the BeanDescriptor and the PropertyDescriptors for this class
        */
        public BeanDescriptor getBeanDescriptor() {
                return BEAN_DESCRIPTOR;
        }

        public PropertyDescriptor[] getPropertyDescriptors() {
                return PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS;
        }
}

The BeanDescriptor provides information to GrALoG about the bean as a whole. The BeanDescriptor allows you to specify the following:

  • A Customizer for this bean. This is optional. For most of your beans you do not have to specify a Customizer. A Customizer is only necessary, in case you want to provide your own {java.awt.Component} that allows the user to customize this bean - this Component is then displayed in GrALoG. Describing the usage of Customizer is beyond the scope of this introduction, please look at Customizer or at Java Bean Specification, if you want to implement your own Customizer.
  • A displayname for this bean. This is also optional and is currently only supported for GrALoG-Algorithms, whose displayname is shown as a name for the algorithm. Set the displayname with FeatureDescriptor.setDisplayName( String name ).
  • A shortdescription for this bean. This is optional and currently only supported by GrALoG-Algorithms and Structure-Beans, whose shortDescription provides a description for this algorithm / structure-bean to the user. Note that you can use arbitrary <html> with this description.
  • A PersistenceDelegate for this bean. This is optional and is only necessary when your bean can not be stored using the DefaultPersistenceDelegate. The DefaultPersistenceDelegate stores respectively loads a bean by calling it's empty constructor and setting / getting all properties for this bean. This is sufficient for most beans in GrALoG.

    Since describing PersistenceDelegates is beyond the scope of this introduction we again refer you to Java Bean Specification respectively the documentation for XMLEncoder. See also de.hu.gralog.algorithm.result.pd de.hu.gralog.structure.pd for examples on how to implement PersistenceDelegates. You can specify your own PersistenceDelegate for a bean by calling FeatureDescriptor.setValue( String, Object) where the first parameter has to be the String "persistenceDelegate" and the second has to be an instance of your PersistenceDelegate-class.

The next thing you have to specify are PropertyDescriptors for each property of your bean. PropertyDescriptor can be used to specify descriptions and PropertyEditors for each property of your bean. They can also be used to define you own getter and setter-functions for this bean, which can be useful in case you do not want or can not use the naming conventions of JavaBeans. For a full description of all features of PropertyDescriptors please refer to it's documentation. The following features are usually used by GrALoG-Beans:

  • A shortDescription for your property that is displayed in GrALoG. You can specify a shortDescription for your property by calling FeatureDescriptor.setShortDescription( String ). Note the shortDescription can again be an arbitrary <html>-String.
  • A PropertyEditor for your property. You can set the PropertyEditor for your property by calling PropertyDescriptor.setPropertyEditorClass( Class editor ).

    GrALoG has a set of special PropertyDescriptors with their own associated PropertyEditors that you can find in de.hu.gralog.beans.propertydescriptor. Feel free to add your own PropertyDescriptor, if you need more functionality.

Please refer to SimpleBeanInfo for information why our BeanInfoClass has the given structure, i.e. overrides the functions SimpleBeanInfo.getBeanDescriptor() and SimpleBeanInfo.getPropertyDescriptors().

Note this was an introduction to the features needed equally for all beans in GrALoG, i.e. Algorithms, Structure-Beans, vertices and edges. For some of these Beans you need to implement extra functionality to allow GrALoG to properly interact with these beans. Please refer to de.hu.gralog.algorithm for specialities concerning Algorithm-Beans in GrALoG, StructureBeanFactory for specialities concerning Structure-Beans and de.hu.gralog.structure.types.elements for specialities concerning beans for vertices and edges in GrALoG.
